body:
You should ensure that all the methods of the standard PreparedStatement and Statement work seamlessly with the multi-queries statements. If a particular method doesn't make sense or can't work correctly, then it is better to return an error. For eg. addBatch, executeBatch etc.

In case of select statement, I couldn't figure out how result sets from different select statements are interfacing with the application. 

The transaction boundaries needs to be explained too for both autocommit and non-autocommit mode.

Sorry for taking a while to respond, @liuyu000. It's good that the RAND() function behaves ok for simple cases, but I think it will not behave that way for some other cases. Here is one example:

```
create table tr(a int not null primary key, b int);
insert into tr values
(0,0),
( 200000000,  200000000),
( 400000000,  400000000),
( 600000000,  600000000),
( 800000000,  800000000),
(1000000000, 1000000000),
(1200000000, 1200000000),
(1400000000, 1400000000),
(1600000000, 1600000000),
(1800000000, 1800000000),
(2000000000, 2000000000),
(2147483647, 2147483647);

set statistics on;
select * from tr where a > rand();
select * from tr where b > rand();
```

When I execute this, I see that the first query uses the predicate as a key predicate, evaluating it only once. The second query uses the predicate as an executor predicate, evaluating it for every row. This leads to a very different behavior of these two queries.

This is similar as UUID(), I will add documentation of UUID asap. So @liuyu000  can refer to my documentation of UUID, if you can wait for a while. 
Or I think one note can be added here , is it OK @zellerh ? Or maybe some better words for Liu Yu?

Rand() function is non-deterministic and can cause unexpected side effect. It can evaluate once or per row depending on the optimizer. So it can only be used in very few places, please do not use it in a predicate.
Yes, something like your note would work. It is probably a good idea to use similar words for both uuid and rand.

No we don't allow for the lcoation to change between compiletime and  runtime. We'll just get an error at  runtime saying the LOB data was not found. Yes the initial design allowed for changes or even each LOB handle's data being stored in potentially different locations. But right now we have jsut one location since the LOB data is stored in  HDFS . If it was Linux and if we go back to storing LOBs on mounted linux drives, we may want to allow for different locations again. But for now this extra CLI call is slowing down each extract or Update call especially during streaming access.
Thanks Dave for the pointing out formatting issue and for the message reminder.
Previous Test Aborted. New Check Test Started: https://jenkins.esgyn.com/job/Check-PR-master/2593/
something wrong with my PR, most changes not in the PR. Close it.

Recovered, PR is now OK...
@anoopsharma00 @DaveBirdsall @zellerh , please help to take a review

@zellerh @traflm thanks for your reivew :)
I've incorporated your NOTE @traflm, and will keep an eye on your documentation of UUID.
This PR is not ready, far from ready, sorry, let me close it.
Are we preparing the query every time with literals? Would it be better to prepare the query once and execute it via a rowset and/or one row at a time?

I will need to maintain 5 internal statements if I do so. Besides, it is difficult to use prepare and execute api of internal statement(data need to be organized again). So I'm not sure if it is better that use rowset. Another question, will compiler and executor handle query with same structure at second time faster? If so, I think it is better to do above than moving all data again(use rowset). This is my opinion, welcome to correct me. Thanks for your question. @selvaganesang
reopen just for some tests, Do not merge
Previous Test Aborted. New Check Test Started: https://jenkins.esgyn.com/job/Check-PR-master/2598/

The current change may be functionally good.  JIRA mentioned something like "query performance will degrade".

If the query in the JIRA refers to the user query, then repository writing is in a different thread and context that of the user query. Hence, it is not in the user query execution path.  

If the query performance refers to the repository queries, I am not sure batching the query to execdirect at once may not improve the sub-micro second execution of the insert statement.. It might  turn it out to be a drag to add the individual SQL string into a vector and process it one by one. There is no process hop other than writing the data to hbase.

Each SQL statement converts the numeric data into a string to form the SQL string at the repository thread and the SQL engine would reverse it to numeric data to be pushed to hbase layer.   Rowset concept could avoid these conversions.

However, if you could demonstrate the stated goal in the JIRA,, please go ahead and merge this PR.

If a mxosrvr aborts, we would the entire cache, not just the last query stats. I would suggest to change the default value for statisticsCacheSize to be 1 to preserve the current behavior where repository updates are done as and when things change. Explicitly override the default to larger value to enable caching.

I made a simple test, using jdbct4 to execute query 'insert into song values(i)' 10k times. MXOSRVR needs to spend more than about 40% (11mins vs 17mins)time writing statistics into repository. I just used one user thread to insert. 
ENV: centos6.7 16GMEM  2 MXOSRVR .

Type    | Cache size|row in METRIC_QUERY_TABLE|ueser query CPU (AVG) | free memory percent|repos CPU |start time| user query finish time | repos finish time(all finish)|
----|---------------|-----------|----------------------------------|--------------------|----------|------|---|-----------------------|
Cache   | 100 |      43101->53111 |    35-38  | 62.4%->60.2% |   24-28 |10.16:11 |  10:19:03 | 10:27:54|
No Cache| 1   |      53124->63142 |    35-38  | 58.0%->52.4% |   24-29 |10.39:47  | 10:42:13 | 10:56:22|
Cache   | 500 |      63161->73150 |    35-38  | 54.1%->50.5% |   24-31 |11.03:02  | 11:05:42 | 11:13:30|

@selvaganesang 
It is only a simple test.
@selvaganesang thanks for your review comments, I add some fix, please help to review again.
It will be better to add a test case for this fix.

Thanks @CoderSong2015 for sharing your test results. It is really incomprehensible to figure out where the improvement in performance came from especially when the data is not batched up and sent to HBase.  Anyway the results are encouraging.  

It looks like you have enabled the statistics for the sub-second queries  to be written to the repository.  It looks like insert statement took less than 3 mins for 10,000 user queries while it took 11 mins in the best case to write the statistics for these queries.   So, in a real environment where the system is loaded without a breather you could end up with lot of catch up to do in the thread where repository statistics are written.  Also, you would need a very large cluster for statistics collection alone. Hence the earlier design had a concept of session statistics which captured just enough information representing the work done in the session. I am assuming that at least these session level statistics are written to repository without caching to avoid the catch-up in the repository thread.

BTW, if you can repeat the testing again, please issue the command "GET PROCESS STATISTICS FOR <nid>, <pid>" at a regular intervals during the test from trafci or sqlci. The nid and pid are the logical node id and pid of the mxosrvr used for connection during your testing.

The output from this command would help us to figure out if anything else is getting queued up in the user query thread.

It turns out permission denied. 
I have to go through the coprocessor I think. 
Will rework.

@selvaganesang I have written an email to trafodion community and gotten the answer why there is improvement in performance. Your second question that why speed of writing the statistics is so slow deserves continuing research.  I will create another JIRA to find it out.

+1
IMHO this is a good default behavior and I hope there will be very few people who need to revert back to the OFF setting of this CQD. In a previous life I lived many years with the OFF setting without any complaints from users - until it happened one day...
Previous Test Aborted. New Check Test Started: https://jenkins.esgyn.com/job/Check-PR-master/2611/

It looks like the weakReference of Statement object is removed. The weakReference is used to implicitly close the statement to clean up the resources associated with the Statement object if the application doesn't explicitly close the statement. This is to take care of resource leaks in the SQL side.  Are there any other alternatives added to take care of such resource leaks. If not, I would suggest this PR may not be merged.

@selvaganesang the weakReference still exist, I just refactor the construction of TrafT4Statement & TrafT4PreparedStatement, each time invoke TrafT4MultiQueriesStatement or TrafT4MultiQueriesPreparedStatement or TrafT4PreparedStatement, there will invoke the construction of TrafT4Statement, in which there will make the statement weakReference.
see line 1415 of TrafT4Statement, it's just fold in the page.

@selvaganesang thanks for your review comments, I add some fix, please help to review again.
In my own workstation, all components Trafodion and HBase running using same userID. In the regression test and in real use case, they are running in different userID.
So I changed the code to use Coporocessor, Trafodion send request to HBase Region Server to change the storage policy of the data path, so running under HBase userID.
Others no change
The Jenkins failure is caused by pyodbc test, I will fix it ASAP

There is no way to remove the CF as far as I know.
It is harmless, the extra CF never contains value, so no HFile will be generated. 
It is an extra Store for HBase, I am not quite clear its impact yet.
But since it is never used, so I remove it here.
